seem able to perform tasks that,
had a human being performed them, would certainly count as thinking. Not
only can computers perform complex calculations very rapidly, they can also
play  an  excellent  game  of  chess.  Do  machines  think?  The  question  seems
forced on us, and it is more than a semantic quibble. In deciding it, we are
also reevaluating the status of an aspect of humanity that has long been con-
sidered its unique or distinctive feature. Once we decide whether machines
